title: 107_s2710
content: The Act titled "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" provides a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 offers a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage determined based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The credit is subject to limitations based on the number of employees and the type of coverage, with a maximum of $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage per employee. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' refers to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50 percent of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week, excluding those eligible for subsidized health plans or benefits under other employers. The definition of 'health insurance coverage' is based on section 9832(b)(1), disregarding the last sentence of section 9832(b)(2). The term 'employee' includes individuals who are entitled to certain benefits under various sections of the Social Security Act, Title XIX or XXI, or specific chapters of the United States Code. The term 'employee' excludes certain individuals under section 401(c)(1) but includes leased employees under section 414(n). Wages are defined as per section 3121(a). Rules similar to section 52 apply, and no double benefits are allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. This credit is part of the general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The employee health insurance expenses credit is part of the general business credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No carrybacks are allowed for this credit before January 1, 2003. The employee health insurance expenses credit can be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2003. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses for coverage established after the enactment of this Act, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
